u20kars_h: This has been a conversation happening everywhere over and over and I don’t where else to put this so here I go. I think the issue with not being okay with the idea of all men are trash is that we refuse to understand the role of implicit bias in making men the product of patriarchy. Just like all straight people are homophobic by default as they just don’t have previous experiences to base their judgement on, all men are sexist given that they have no previous experience of being a women to base it on. Privilege here is more than just being a men, it’s about the ability of refusal to listen as it shatters and changes your world view. I mean as someone who finds masculinity as a part of my identity and redefining it as a part of the process of being comfortable with myself, the notion of calling men trash does hit home. It can feel very dehumanising to have to challenge that identity but I don’t think that’s enough of a reason to give the larger idea of this away. Men are trash is an expression of not frustration but education that allows us to think within about how our privilege makes us stand better off in the world.

diaries_of_mad_moon: Here are my views. Hoping for a discussion. 1. Today sexism is not confined to men only. Every man, who grew up to be a sexist, had probably been influenced by both men and women in their lives in every aspect, including gender sensitivity. So, I think not just all men, but every human. In this sense, all men seems a bit narrow. 2. At some point in life, we make choices - political inclination, religious beliefs, societal rights and wrongs etc. So, many a times, when people say that patriarchy originated from men, hence men are the accountable even for those women who regress women. Then it seems like at some point it is a choice everyone, irrespective of sex, has to make - whether to continue what I was told and taught or to break the mould, just like, say, the child of a smoker may or may not become a smoker. 3. Does all men take into consideration that the men who actually want gender equality may feel disappointed that they, despite not causing harm, are being made to feel unjustified and could it not hamper their mental health?
